Su Guo Gong Shiyi Qianhu Hu Cizi Zeng Sigong Shi Daguan Zheng Hao Daguanghui Daxingshansi Sanzang Shamen Bukong Respectfully Translated by Imperial Decree Thus have I heard:
At one time the BhagavÄn was dwelling in RÄjagá¹›ha on Vulture Peak Mountain, together with a great bhiká¹£u assembly of 1,250 people, and a great assembly of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
At that time, the venerable ÅšÄriputra went to the place where Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Maitreya was practicing walking meditation.
Maitreya Bodhisattva and ÅšÄriputra both sat on a flat rock.
At that time, the venerable ÅšÄriputra asked Maitreya Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, saying:
Today the World-Honored One observed rice sheaves and told the bhiká¹£us these words:
'You bhiká¹£us!
If you see dependent origination, you see the Dharma;
If one sees the Dharma, one sees the Buddha.
Having spoken thus, the BhagavÄn remained silent.
What is the meaning of this sÅ«tra spoken by the TathÄgata?
What is dependent origination?
What is the Dharma?
What is the Buddha?
How does seeing dependent origination mean seeing the Dharma?
How does seeing the Dharma mean seeing the Buddha?
Having said this, the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva Maitreya said to ÅšÄriputra:
The BhagavÄn always speaks this meaning for the bhiká¹£us:
'If one sees dependent origination, one sees the Dharma;
if one sees the Dharma, one sees the Buddha.'

Dependent origination refers to the arising of formations conditioned by ignorance, the arising of consciousness conditioned by formations, the arising of name-and-form conditioned by consciousness, the arising of the six sense bases conditioned by name-and-form, the arising of contact conditioned by the six sense bases, the arising of feeling conditioned by contact, the arising of craving conditioned by feeling, the arising of clinging conditioned by craving, the arising of existence conditioned by clinging, the arising of birth conditioned by existence, and the arising of old age and death conditioned by birth.
The TathÄgata speaks of this as dependent origination.
What is the Dharma?
The TathÄgata briefly explains that the eightfold noble path leads to the attainment of nirvÄá¹‡a, and this is called the Dharma.
What is the Buddha?

Because he has awakened to all dharmas, he has realized nirvÄá¹‡a with the eye of holy wisdom, and he has seen the dharmas that are to be practiced by those who cultivate bodhi. This is called the Buddha.
What is meant by seeing dependent origination?

The TathÄgata says that this dependent origination is permanent, without a person, without a self, without sentient beings, without a life principle, not inverted, unborn, uncreated, unconditioned, without an object, and unobstructed.
Seeing its inherent quiescence is seeing the Dharma.

If one sees this kind of permanence, without a person, without a self, without sentient beings, without a life principle, not inverted, unborn, without an object, and unobstructed, then one sees the Dharma.
After this, one sees the Dharma body and sees the TathÄgata, directly realizing right wisdom.
He also asked:
What is the meaning of 'dependent origination'?
He replied:
It is called dependent origination because there are causes and conditions, not without causes and conditions. The TathÄgata has briefly explained the characteristics of dependent origination.
Because of this cause, it can give rise to this effect.

Whether the TathÄgata appears in the world or not, the nature of dharmas, the abiding of dharmas, the stage of dharmas, accords with dependent origination, true suchness, non-inverted suchness, non-different suchness, the non-difference of reality, the non-inversion of reality, and non-error. It is like this and so forth.
Furthermore, dependent origination arises from two kinds of causes.
What are the two?
First, the cause to which one is bound; second, the conditions to which one is bound.
One should know that the dharmas of dependent origination are of two kinds, namely external and internal.
What is the cause to which the external dependent origination is bound?
Namely, from seeds sprouts arise, from sprouts leaves arise, from leaves branches arise, from branches stems arise, from stems trunks arise, from trunks flowers arise, and from flowers fruits arise.
If there were no seeds, sprouts would have nothing to arise from, and up to flowers and fruits would also have nothing to arise from.
Because there are seeds, sprouts arise, and up to because there are flowers, fruits arise. The seeds do not think:
'I can give rise to sprouts.'
The sprouts also do not think:
'I arise from seeds.'
Up to the flowers also do not think:
'I can give rise to fruits.'
The fruits also do not think:
'I arise from flowers.'
However, because there are seeds, sprouts arise, and up to because there are flowers, fruits arise.
Thus, external dependent arising should be understood as being subject to causes.
How is external dependent arising subject to conditions?
It is said that the six elements coming together and giving rise to things are subject to conditions.
What are the six elements?
Earth, water, fire, wind, space, and time come together as conditions, and arise dependent on conditions.
What are the earth element, water, fire, wind, space, and time element?
Causing the seed to be held, it is called the earth element;
Causing the seed to be moistened, it is called the water element;ğŸ”½Causing the seed to be accomplished, it is called the fire element;
Causing the seed to grow, it is called the wind element;
Causing the seed to be unobstructed, it is called the space element;
Causing the seed to change, it is called the time element.
If there are no conditions, the seed does not produce a sprout.
If the earth element is not lacking, and the water, fire, wind, space, and time elements are not lacking, then all come together, and the seed produces a sprout.
The earth element does not think:
'I can hold the seed.'
The water element does not think:
'I can moisten the seed.'
The fire element does not think:
'I can accomplish the seed.'
The wind element does not think:
'I can make the seed grow.'
The space element does not think:
'I can make the seed unobstructed.'
The time element does not think:
'I can transform the seed.'
The seed also does not think:
'I am born from various conditions and produce a sprout.'

However, if there are these conditions, the seed produces a sprout. The sprout is not self-made, not made by another, not made by both, not made by the Lord of Creation, not made by time, not born from its own nature, and not dependent on anything else. It is not born without a cause.
Thus, the seed is born due to the combination of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and time.
This external dependent origination should be known in five ways:
Not permanent, not discontinuous, not transferred, with little cause but abundant effect, with a continuous similarity, not producing different things.
Why is it not permanent?
Because the seed and sprout are different, it is not that the seed is the sprout, nor is it that the sprout arises from the destruction of the seed.
Because the seed actually perishes and the sprout arises, and because the sprout arises from the destruction of the seed, it is called impermanent.
Why is it not discontinuous?
The sprout arises without the seed being destroyed beforehand, nor without it being destroyed.
In this way, the seed perishes and the sprout arises from the combination, called non-discontinuous.
Not transferred means that the seed and sprout are different.
With little cause but abundant effect means that the seed is small but the fruit is abundant.
With a continuous similarity means that according to the seed that is planted, the fruit that is harvested is also like that.
In this way, the five aspects of externally arisen conditioned factors should be understood.
What is internally arisen conditioned arising?
There are two kinds of arising.
What are the two kinds?
First, the cause of dependence, and second, the conditions of dependence.
How are the internal dependent origination dharmas dependent on causes?
Namely, ignorance conditions formations, up to birth conditions old age and death.
If there were no ignorance, then there would be no formations. However, with ignorance, there are formations, up to with birth, old age and death can arise.
Ignorance does not think like this:
'I can give rise to formations.'
Formations do not think like this:
'I arise from ignorance.'
Up to birth does not think like this:
'I can give rise to old age and death.'
However, with ignorance, formations arise, up to with birth, old age and death arise.
Thus, the internal dependent origination dharmas are dependent on causes.
How are the internal dependent origination dharmas dependent on conditions?
The six elements come together and give rise [to existence].
How do the six elements come together?
Namely, the combination of the earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements arises through conditions and is dependent on conditions.
What is the earth element?
It causes the body to be aggregated and solid, and is called the earth element.
What is the water element?
It causes the body to be held together, and is called the water element.
What is the fire element?
It causes food and drink to be digested in the body, and is called the fire element.
What is the wind element?
It causes inhalation and exhalation in the body, and is called the wind element.
What is the space element?
It causes cavities and openings to be formed in the body, and is called the space element.
What is the consciousness element?
It causes name-and-form to revolve like a bundle of reeds, and the defiled mental consciousness associated with the five consciousnesses is called the consciousness element.
If there were no six elements, the body would not be formed.
If the internal earth element is not lacking, and the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements are not lacking, then all combined can give rise to the body.
The earth element does not think:
'I can cause the body to gather and form a solid substance.'
The water element does not think:
'I can cause the body to be held together.'
The fire element does not think:
'I can cause the food and drink in the body to be digested.'
The wind element does not think:
'I can cause the body to breathe in and out.'
The space element does not think:
'I can cause cavities to be formed in the body.'
The consciousness element also does not think:
'I can cause name-and-form to be like a bundle of reeds.'
The body also does not think:
'I am produced by various conditions.'
However, there are such various conditions that produce the body.

This earth element is without self, without person, without life, without vitality, without one who is born, without one who has grown, without female, without male, without neither female nor male, without me, and also without others.

The elements of water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness are also without self, without person, without life, without longevity, without mind-born, without youth, without female, without male, without non-male and non-female, without I, and without other.
What is ignorance?

In these six elements, one gives rise to the notion of oneness, the notion of combination, the notion of permanence, the notion of solidity, the notion of constancy, the notion of bliss, the notion of tranquility, the notion of sentient beings, the notion of life, the notion of longevity, the notion of mind-born, the notion of youth, and the notion of I as the doer.
Giving rise to such various kinds of ignorance is called ignorance.
In the realm of such ignorance, craving, anger, and delusion arise. In that craving, anger, and delusion, formations arise.
In that matter, it is designated as consciousness, and the consciousness gives rise to the four aggregates.
That name-and-form depends on the faculties, which are the six sense bases.
The combination of the three factors is called contact.
Contact gives rise to feeling.
Because of receiving and indulging in it, love arises.
Because love expands greatly, it is called grasping.
Grasping further gives rise to existence.
Karmic existence creates the cause for the arising of the aggregates.
Because the aggregates mature, it is called aging;
Because the aggregates disintegrate, it is called death;
Because of delusion, attachment, and distress towards love, it is called sorrow;
Because of pursuing past events and lamenting in a mournful voice, it is called lamentation;
Associated with the five sense consciousnesses, it is called suffering;
Because of mental dissatisfaction, it is called grief;
Because of following afflictions, it is called distress.
Ignorance is called nescience;
Fabrication is called karmic formations;
Discernment is called consciousness;
Mutual inclusion is called name-and-form;
The basis of dependence is called the six sense bases;ğŸ”½Contacting objects is called contact;
Sensation is called feeling;
Thirst is called craving;
Attachment is called grasping;
Grasping again produces existence, therefore it is called existence;
Because it can give rise to, it is called birth;
Because the faculties mature, it is called old age;
Because of destruction, it is called death;ğŸ”½Because of sorrow, it is called grief;
Because of dispiritedness, it is called lamentation;
Because of mental dissatisfaction, it is called worry;
Because of oppression of the body, it is called suffering;
Because of not conforming to one's feelings, it is called distress.
Not cultivating true practice is called wrong practice;
Lack of knowledge is called ignorance.

Because of the existence of ignorance, various kinds of meritorious near-practice, unmeritorious near-practice, and immovable near-practice are created.ğŸ”½Because of giving rise to meritorious near-practice and unmeritorious near-practice, it is called consciousness, therefore it is called ignorance as a condition for volitional formations.
Because of giving rise to unmeritorious near-practice and unmeritorious near-practice, it is also just consciousness, therefore it is called volitional formations as a condition for consciousness.
The practice of the immovable near-action and the practitioner of the immovable near-action are also based on consciousness, therefore it is called name-and-form conditioned by consciousness.
Name-and-form grows and becomes the six sense bases, therefore it is called six sense bases conditioned by name-and-form.
The six sense bases turn into the body, therefore it is called contact conditioned by the six sense bases.
Contact of the same kind produces feeling of the same kind, therefore it is called feeling conditioned by contact.
Distinguishing and clinging to feeling with delight, therefore it is called craving conditioned by feeling.
Craving clings to pleasure, therefore craving does not let go, and repeatedly seeks with joy, therefore it is called grasping conditioned by craving.
Seeking like this, it further gives rise to existence and creates karma in the body, speech, and mind, therefore it is called becoming conditioned by grasping.
The five aggregates arising from karma turn, called birth conditioned by becoming.
From birth, the aggregates ripen and perish, called old age and death conditioned by birth.
This is called the twelve links of dependent origination.

They are mutually causes, not permanent, not created, not intentional, also not arisen from conditions, not an exhausted dharma, not a dharma free from desire, not a ceased dharma, and have been flowing and turning without interruption since beginningless time, turning like a swiftly flowing river.
If conditioned arising flows and turns without interruption like a swiftly flowing river, then in this twelve-linked dependent arising, four links combine to form the cause of turning.
What are the four?
Namely, ignorance, craving, karma, and consciousness.
This consciousness, whose nature is a seed, is the cause, karma, whose nature is a field, is the cause, and ignorance and craving, whose nature is afflictions, are the cause.
Karma, afflictions, and consciousness can produce seeds.
In this way, karma and consciousness act as the field for the seeds, craving and consciousness act as the nourishing moisture for the seeds, and ignorance and consciousness cause the seeds to sprout.
That karma does not think:
'I act as the field for the seeds of consciousness.'
Craving does not think:
'I provide moisture for the seed of consciousness.'
Ignorance does not think:
'I cause the seed of consciousness to develop.'
The seed of consciousness also does not think:
'I am born from various conditions.'
However, in reality, the seed of consciousness is established by karma and afflictions, moistened by craving, and covered by the soil of ignorance, giving rise to the sprout of name-and-form.

That sprout of name-and-form is not self-made, not made by another, not made by both, not made by ÄªÅ›vara, not made by time, not born from self-nature, not dependent on causes, and not born without causes. However, it is born from the union of parents and the coming together of other conditions.
That seed of consciousness gives rise to the sprout of name-and-form in the mother's womb.
In the absence of a master, a giver, and a recipient, in the illusory nature of phenomena, when the conditions are not lacking, eye-consciousness arises from five conditions.
What are the five?
The eye depends on form, light, and space, and arises from attention.
Eye consciousness takes the eye as its basis, form as its object, light as its illumination, space as its unobstructed condition, and attention as its investigation.
If these conditions are absent, eye consciousness does not arise.
If the internal eye faculty is lacking, and likewise form, light, space, and attention, then eye consciousness does not arise.
Thus, when these five conditions are not lacking, they all come together and give rise to eye consciousness.
The eye does not think:
'I provide a basis for eye consciousness.'
Form does not think:
'I am the object for eye consciousness.'
Light does not think:
'I provide illumination for eye consciousness.'
Space does not think:
'I provide an unobstructed condition for eye consciousness.'
The mind that is generated does not think:
'I assist the eye consciousness in making judgments.'
Also, the eye consciousness does not think:
'I am born from many conditions.'
However, the eye consciousness is born from many conditions.
The other four faculties should be understood as before.
In reality, there is no dharma that moves from this world to the other shore.
However, there is the establishment of karmic retribution, because the conditions are not lacking.
For example, a bright mirror reflects a face, and the face does not move to the mirror, yet there is the reflection of the face in the mirror, because the conditions are not lacking.
In the same way, it does not move from here to the other shore.
However, there is the attraction of the results of karma, because the conditions are not lacking.

For example, the moon is forty thousand yojanas away from the earth. If there is a small amount of water in a complete vessel, then a reflection of the moon appears. However, it does not actually disappear from there and appear in the small amount of water in the complete vessel. However, when the many conditions come together, the reflection appears in this way.
It does not cease here and arise elsewhere, because the characteristics of karmic retribution and causal conditions are not lacking.
For example, without firewood, fire does not arise;
with firewood, fire arises.
The seeds of consciousness produced by karma and afflictions continue from that place of birth, and the sprouts of name-and-form evolve.
Thus, in dharmas without a master, without a self, and without appropriation, the causal conditions are mutually dependent, and the characteristics and natures of illusions are not lacking.
The five aspects of internal dependent arising should be known:
not permanent, not discontinuous, not transferring, with small causes and great effects, and producing a continuous succession of similar [effects].
Why is it not permanent?
From the aggregates at the time of death, one is born with the aggregates at the time of birth in another place;
it is not that the aggregates at the time of death are the aggregates at the time of birth;
however, the aggregates at the time of death cease, and the aggregates at the time of birth arise. Therefore, it is not permanent.
Why is it not discontinuous?
It is not that the aggregates at the time of death cease first, and then the aggregates at the time of birth arise;
nor is it that without the cessation of the aggregates at the time of death, the intermediate state aggregates arise at that time, like a scale neither dipping nor rising, this is called not cut off.
What is meant by not transferred?
However, it is called not transferred because it continues in a different category.
What is meant by the effect is greater than the cause?
Having done a small amount of good or evil karma in this body, one receives much good or evil retribution in the body of the next life.
What is meant by continuity of similarity?
It is just like the karma of the body that is currently experienced, and the retribution that is received in the next life.

If this dependent origination is truly cultivated for a long time with the eye of right wisdom, there is no person, no self, no inversion, no arising, no cessation, no action, no conditioning, no obstruction, no object, tranquility, fearlessness, no deprivation, no exhaustion, like an illusion, the nature of emptiness and quiescence, not solid, like pain, like a boil, obstructive, the nature of impermanence, the nature of suffering, the nature of emptiness, the nature of no-self, then there is no flowing and turning in the past, namely:ğŸ”½'Did I exist in the past?
Who was I in the past?
How did I exist in the past?'
And there is also flowing and turning in the future, namely:
'Will I exist in the future?ğŸ”½Who will I be in the future?
How will I exist in the future?
Will I not exist in the future?
Who will say I will not exist in the future?'
How will I not exist in the future?
And in the present, they do not flow:
Do I exist now?ğŸ”½Who says I exist now?
How does one say I exist now?
Where will this being go after death?

Whatever views of self, views of sentient beings, views of life, views of person, hopes, and attachments to auspiciousness there are among ascetics and brahmins in the world, if one is endowed with right view, at that time all those bonds are cut, and one attains complete knowledge.

Like cutting down a palmyra tree, one enters into the nature of non-existence, into the ultimate truth, and for a long time in all destinies one realizes non-arising and non-cessation, and attains the acceptance of non-arising, and extensively performs boundless deeds of benefiting and bringing happiness to sentient beings.

If there are good sons and good women who contemplate the meaning and principles of dependent origination in this sutra for even a short while, they will be able to suddenly extinguish the extremely heavy karmic hindrances accumulated since beginningless time, extensively gather merit and virtue, penetrate wisdom, forever sever wrong views, and speak the Dharma fearlessly.
Venerable ÅšÄriputra!
The Blessed One will bestow the prediction of supreme perfect enlightenment and great bodhi upon those good sons and good women.
